column4: I have 2 internal HD's on my laptop (Sony Viao).  I want to MOVE my /home directory from one HD (SDA1) to the other . . . any ideas how?
create your new home partition.. copy *everything* to the new home.. change in fstab.. reboot
before you clicked the "generate download script" did you mark any packages in the list?
Well shit, I feel like an ass . . . I highlighted them, I didn't "Check" them.
=).. give it a try..
okay, yeah . . . the script built just fine, but the problem is that the target computer has no internet & how to I make sure all dependencies get satisfied?
okay, yeah . . . the script built just fine, but the problem is that the target computer has no internet & how to I make sure all dependencies get satisfied?
now you save that script on a big flash drive and go run it on a computer that does have an internet connection
it's basically the same as aptoncd.. but with a little more manual work
Oh, and it'll just download to the flash drive?  Do I need to specify somewhere that the Flashdrive is the target?  And will it just pull the Dependencies automatically?
I think it will download it to the same directory as the script file.. it's just a simple text file that runs some wget commands.. open it up and look at it
Yeah, I did open it . . . and it is just wget commands.  Do you know anything about the dependencies?
if the dependencies get "marked" too I think they will be included.. but if you go back far enough it will depend on almost everything that is in the default install..
so if it did recursive dependencies you would end up downloading all the packages in the install cd..
Okay, thanks.
Okay, thanks.
What is a "Recursive Dependensies"?  And I checked, Synaptic does (at least for me) auto select dependencies.
I meant for example,  you install openoffice, it depends on gnome, gnome depends on X and so on..

That's exactly what I mean, everything seems to depend on everything else . . . it's beyond irritating . . . that you know of (or anyone reading this), is there some magical thing to type [  sudo apt-get install depedencies ndiswrapper  ] to just make it work?  I'll be trying to satisfy dependencies for days if I do it one by one!
why is that irritating? apt-get will only install the stuff you need to run the program..  the base stuff should already be installed

Yeah, that's what I was thinking.  For instance, the target computer needs "dpkg", which has nearly 30 dependencies itself.  Either I download just dpkg, or I (to "save" time) download them all, and THEN each of THOSE things has 20 dependencies, that's the irritating part.
ahh.. but you create the synaptic script on the computer that needs the packages... then it will just download the stuff that it needs
Okay, i'll just hold my breath & try it.
